channel.title: Comments on: Why use parenthesis on JavaScript return statements?

item.title: By: Stuart
item.dc:creator: Stuart
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/javascript-return-parenthesis/#comment-22650">James K Nelson</a>.
And 'curly brackets' } too?! :)
Yeah, in the UK we tend to call them 'brackets' as well
item.content:encoded:
In reply to James K Nelson.

And ‘curly brackets’ } too?! ðŸ™‚

Yeah, in the UK we tend to call them ‘brackets’ as well

item.title: By: Matt Fysh
item.dc:creator: Matt Fysh
item.description: Nice article! Also helpful to use a linter, such as eslint, to detect unreachable code paths before pushing your code to git
item.content:encoded: Nice article! Also helpful to use a linter, such as eslint, to detect unreachable code paths before pushing your code to git

item.title: By: Ben Frain
item.dc:creator: Ben Frain
item.description:
And a British thing. ;)
Thank for the post James, I learnt something new this morning. That makes me happy!
item.content:encoded:
And a British thing. ðŸ˜‰

Thank for the post James, I learnt something new this morning. That makes me happy!

item.title: By: James K Nelson
item.dc:creator: James K Nelson
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/javascript-return-parenthesis/#comment-22648">Brian Capouch</a>.
No significance. I've always called them brackets. Maybe it is an Aussie thing?
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Brian Capouch.

No significance. I’ve always called them brackets. Maybe it is an Aussie thing?

item.title: By: Brian Capouch
item.dc:creator: Brian Capouch
item.description: Curious whether there is any significance to your use of the term "bracket" in this post for what I would call a "parenthesis."
item.content:encoded: Curious whether there is any significance to your use of the term “bracket” in this post for what I would call a “parenthesis.”
